content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>United States Geological Survey St. Petersburg Coastal and Marine Science Center</origin> <pubdate>2010 August</pubdate> <title>08FSH01_trackline.shp</title> <geoform>vector digital data</geoform> <serinfo> <sername>Data Series</sername> <issue>535A</issue> </serinfo> <onlink>TBA</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>From August 11 to 15, 2008, a cruise led by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) collected air and sea surface partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2), pH, dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC), and total alkalinity (TA) data on the west Florida shelf. Approximately 1,600 data points were collected underway over a 650-km trackline using the Multiparameter Inorganic Carbon Analyzer (MICA). The collection of data extended from Crystal River Southward to Marco Island, FL (~400 km), and westward up to 160 km off the Florida coast. Discrete water samples were also taken at specific localities to corroborate underway data measurements. The USGS St. Petersburg Coastal and Marine Science Center (SPCMSC) assigns a unique identifier to each cruise or field activity. For example, 08FSH01 tells us the data were collected in 2008 for the Response of Florida Shelf (FSH) Ecosystems to Climate Change project and the data were collected during the first field activity for that study in that calendar year.</abstract> <purpose>Trackline data will allow researchers to georeference seawater chemistry using GIS computer mapping software.</purpose> <supplinf>The global positioning system (GPS) used was a Garmin eTrex Vista HCx linked to ESRI ArcGIS software using the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources DNRGarmin GPS Extension, version 5.3.2 (2/13/2008). The Vista HCx receiver was WAAS/EGNOS enabled with a rated accuracy of < 10 meters and 95 percent typical confidence. Coordinates were written directly to an ArcMap shapefile once or twice per minute.</supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <sngdate> <caldate>2008 August</caldate> </sngdate> </timeinfo> <current>ground condition</current> </timeperd> <status> <progress>Complete</progress> <update>None planned</update> </status> <spdom> <bounding> <westbc>-84.366738</westbc> <eastbc>-81.853419</eastbc> <northbc>29.043569</northbc> <southbc>25.758327</southbc> </bounding> </spdom> <keywords> <theme> <themekt>Ocean Chemistry</themekt> <themekey>Ocean Acidification</themekey> <themekey>pCO2</themekey> <themekey>total carbon</themekey> <themekey>carbon flux</themekey> <themekey>pH</themekey> <themekey>Salinity</themekey> <themekey>Temperature</themekey> </theme> <place> <placekt>None</placekt> <placekey>West Florida Shelf</placekey> <placekey>Florida</placekey> <placekey>United States</placekey> </place> <stratum> <stratkt>Water</stratkt> <stratkey>seawater</stratkey> <stratkey>ocean surface</stratkey> </stratum> </keywords> <accconst>Any use of these data signifies a user's agreement to comprehension and compliance of the USGS Standard Disclaimer. Ensure all portions of metadata are read and clearly understood before using these data in order to protect both user and USGS interests.</accconst> <useconst>This publication was prepared by an agency of the United States Government. The Vista HCx receiver was WAAS/EGNOS enabled with a rated accuracy of less than 10 meters and 95 percent typical confidence.</logic> <complete>The trackline is a series of points traversing the west Florida shelf at varying depth and distance from the coast. Trackline coordinates were written directly to an ArcMap shapefile once or twice per minute.</complete> <lineage> <procstep> <procdesc>Metadata was imported using ArcCatalog and the Federal Geographic
